posts.cooked:
Just wondering if it is possible to laser cut 20DP gears out of 3/8” or 1/2” aluminum?

Our team is building a custom gearbox and need a lot of gears. We have access to a water jet and can get 7075 aluminum slabs for a much cheaper price, so just wondering if this is a possibility or if we just need to bite the bullet and buy the gears.

From my experience with a water jet there is a slight taper in the cutting edge where the top of the cut near the nozzle is a little thinner and the cut is a little wider at the bottom near the table. Most 2d shapes this likely isn’t a problem, but on gears would lead to very poor contact across the face width.  If load capacity is not a big issue you might try it. I have seen teams laser multiple 1/8” sheets and stack them with some good success.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked: I have never seen a waterjet with that small of a nozzle.

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked: We would waterjet cut 20DP teeth on the azimuth body of our swerve module. If I recall, the plate was 1/4 or 5/16 aluminum. We never had any problems with them. BUT, the swerve module rotation was slow. I don’t know how well those gears would have done at higher speeds.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: Not all waterjets are equal.  Some machines can cut these, but using Al gears is a potential problem, with no quick recovery – unless you make spares and can do quick swaps.  It’s probably a good idea to buy the gears, if you can get ones that will work for you, and/or design with off-the-shelf parts.  Even if you cut these yourselves, it might be a good idea to use the same dimensions as a part you can order – in case you need to make a swap.  You will also probably need to run these in before they turn smoothly.

posts.name: waialua3:59
posts.cooked:
nuttle:

Not all waterjets are equal.

This.

posts.name: Connor McBride
posts.cooked: 166 waterjetted our 20DP racks on our intake last year. Worked like a charm.

posts.name: Ryan Stockton
posts.cooked: We have waterjet 20DP gears almost every year for the past 10 years. We have waterjet 32DP gears a few times too. While the taper its visible they have worked just fine for us in low speed mechanisms like turrets, intake deploy mechanisms, and arms. Occasionally we will waterjet 2 meshing gears and flip one of them so the tapers counteract each other. We usually cut with a .022" orifice tip in the machine.
That’s awesome! Glad to hear you’ve had success with waterjetting gears. What material do you use for the gears? Thickness?

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: I regularly used 20dp gears cut on an OMAX water jet for my college robotics team. I usually used 7075-T6 plate but also used 6061 on occasion for lower load use cases. I used both 1/4" and 3/8".
